title: What does not get cleared off your credit report when you file bankrupcy
question: I have student loans . a lot of them makes my credit horrible. Will filing bankruptcy erase them. Will it help. What chapter do I file. Does it cost . thanks in advance
answers:
The issue is not the debt being cleared off "your credit report." Rather, the issue is whether your obligation to pay the debt is, in bankruptcy terms, "discharged." If a debt is discharged, then the credit report must accurately reflect that fact.

So if your question then is whether your student loans will be discharged in a bankruptcy case, the answer (as the other lawyers have said) is "probably not." It is very difficult to discharge student loans in a bankruptcy case. You have to show 1) that if forced to repay, you wouldn't be able to maintain a minimally adequate standard of living, 2) that there are additional circumstances indicating this sate of affairs is likely to continue, and 3) that you have made good faith efforts to repay in the past. Very few people meet this standard, and usually #2 is the sticking point.

But if your question is "will bankruptcy help," the answer is "maybe." For example, if you are being garnished and the lender won't agree to a reasonable repayment plan (if they're private loans), or if you don't qualify for income-driven repayment (if they're federal), you might be able to use a Chapter 13 case to force what is essentially a 5-year forbearance on them.

So all in all, you need to talk to a lawyer. Your situation is unique, and a lawyer would need more facts about your specific situation to help you figure out if & how the Bankruptcy Court can help. Does it cost? It will not be free, but a lawyer will lay out what would be accomplished and what the fees would be, and you can make the decision if it makes sense for you.

The general rule is that student loans are not dischargeable. However, there are some exceptions. I recommend you contact a student loan BK specialist lawyer for a free consultation. D.J. Rausa in San Diego is one of the best. Contact him by phone. You won't be disappointed. Good luck with solving your financial problem.

If these are federal loans, there are several programs to resolve these student loans, including income based repayment programs that could be as low as $0/month. But you can't get these deals without applying for them. Yeah, it will cost several hundred bucks to get into these programs if you in default on these loans. Bankruptcy probably the worst way to sove this kind of debt problem. Hope this perspective helps!

Debts do not get 'cleared off' your credit report, they stay on your report and the debt is listed as 'discharged in bankruptcy' and fall off as they age. The debts listed this way are most of your unsecured non priority debts.
Student Loans have a special status and are presumed not discharged unless you ask the court for an order discharging them. This is done by filing a complaint inside the bankruptcy, or after the bankruptcy is discharged. You must pass the hardship test for dischargebility.
If you are threatened with collection actions due to your student loans you may file a chapter 13 which, depending on your judge, will allow you to pay your student loans either as a separate class of creditor or in the same class as the rest of your unsecured non priority creditors.
Depending on whether your student loans are federal and/or private determines whether the creditor will work with you outside of bankruptcy. There are affordable payment plans for federal student loans. The downside is any portion not paid at the end of the plan is considered income and you will receive a 1099 which must be reported on your income tax return for the year you receive the 1099. (If you file an adversary and enter a payment arrangement you may ask that this amount be forgiven through your bankruptcy.) Private student loans become zombie debt if you don't make a payment for 4 years and the creditor fails to sue you. If the creditor sues you you may use any defenses you have and work out a settlement. If you fail to respond to the complaint then the creditor will obtain a default judgment and may garnish your wages, levy your bank accounts, etc. You are in the San Bernardino/Riverside area - I suggest you contact a knowledgeable bankruptcy attorney who handles cases in that area. It pays to hire an attorney who is familiar with the procedures and the judges up there.

as a rule, student loans don't get discharged in bankruptcy. You need to consult with a bankruptcy attorney in your area to answeer all you questions and explain the process to you. You can find some very good ones here on AVVO. Most do not charge for an initial consultation.

Filing bankruptcy will not affect your student loans unless you're eligible for a hardship discharge. I recommend calling attorney Jay fleshman in Pasadena. Or you can Google his website, there's a lot of information about student loans on it.
